Award.AwardTitle: Person perception, reputations, and shared information in the social network context

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research supported by this grant innovates beyond traditional approaches to studying impression formation. Impression formation, which has been a core topic in social psychology for a long time, has generally been treated as a purely cognitive process within one perceiver. This research instead examines impressions in the context of the social network, as emerging when many people interact and share information with others. People's impressions of others are fundamental tools for social life. They influence whether we trust someone's opinion, or choose to befriend, date, or cooperate with someone. While existing research has clarified many of the cognitive processes involved in forming impressions, other important aspects remain unexamined, especially the ways perceivers incorporate information about another person passed along by others rather than relying solely on firsthand observations. A fuller picture of impression formation must involve not only cognitive processes within the individual perceiver, but also dyadic interaction processes through which perceivers actively elicit information from others, and processes of information flow in social networks.

The research proposed uses computational modeling and experimental approaches to address four key questions: (1) How do impressions differ when perceivers can actively choose what and how much information they receive about a person, rather than being limited to a fixed, pre-specified body of information (as in most existing research)? (2) Are perceivers aware of others' general reputations, and how do those reputations affect the perceiver's own impression? (3) Are perceivers aware of potential biases in socially transmitted information and can they correct for such bias? (4) How does asymmetric familiarity influence interpersonal interaction, when person A knows a lot about B (learned from third parties) but B does not know A at all? The research findings resulting from this will have implications for prejudice and stereotyping, which are also constructed and spread through social networks, and will address questions that are important to people's daily lives. In addition to the scientific advances that will result from this work, the project also aims to promote teaching, training, and learning among undergraduate and graduate students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
People’s impressions or mental representations of other individuals are fundamental tools for social life, influencing our choices of romantic partners, friends, and co-workers to collaborate with. Controlled laboratory studies have clarified many cognitive processes involved in person perception. However, other aspects remain unexamined, especially the ways perceivers may incorporate information about the target person passed along from others rather than relying solely on their own firsthand observations. In fact, in everyday life most people discuss new individuals they meet with mutual friends or acquaintances.

Smith and Collins (2009) presented a theoretical model of person perception in its social context, incorporating cognitive processes of information interpretation and integration within an individual perceiver, interaction processes through which perceivers actively elicit information from targets, and processes through which information about people flows through social networks. These processes result in not just an individual’s mental representation of another person, but a patterned reputation of an individual that is shared (more or less consensually) through the social network. Our research under this proposal has employed multi-agent modeling and laboratory experimental approaches to address six areas:

  1. Differences between perceivers who actively choose what and how much information they receive, versus those who are limited to a fixed, pre-specified body of information. For example, we found that perceivers who lack control over how much information they receive about a person form more extreme early impressions.
  2. Perceivers’ awareness of targets’ general reputations, and the effects of reputations above and beyond the perceiver’s own unique impression of the target.  We found that people alter their impressions when they learn what others think of a target, even when they have a good deal of information about the target and believe that the others’ impressions are based on very little information.
  3. Effects of self-disclosing information about oneself, versus passing along information about another person, on the relationship between the communicator and recipient. Past research shows that both of these types of communication increase liking for the communicator, but our studies are the first to directly compare them.
  4. Effects of sending versus receiving a self-disclosure in an encounter with a person from a different ethnic group, on prejudice toward that group.  Existing research shows that exchanges of self-disclosures contribute to prejudice reduction, but do not show which direction of self-disclosure is more effective.  Counterintuitively, our studies show that sending information about oneself to an outgroup member reduces prejudice more than receiving information from an outgroup member.
  5. Further development of the multi-agent model described in Smith and Collins (Psychological Review, 2009), based on the empirical results of the proposed studies. A recent paper used modeling to clarify circumstances in which observers could use information about target persons passed along by third parties, to identify targets who are likely to commit rare but extreme negative acts (and therefore to avoid those targets).
  6.
